fields.description:
Note: This doesn't cause any user-facing problems.

 

While restoring drafts, the file comment form is focused, which requires scrolling the page to that location. The logic we have to scroll there relies on an {{editor}} being initialized, but this happens too early in the page lifecycle for the editor to be ready.

 
{noformat}

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When committing a change made via the new in-browser editor, the commit message dialogue doesn't correctly handle non-latin characters.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Edit any text file using the in-browser editor feature
 # Commit your changes, and use the following commit message: "Вы столкнулись с ошибкой"

h3. Expected Results

In the Commits tab, the message should be rendered correctly
h3. Actual Results

This example message is rendered as "Ð’Ñ ÑÑÐ¾Ð»ÐºÐ½ÑÐ»Ð¸ÑÑ Ñ Ð¾ÑÐ¸Ð±ÐºÐ¾Ð¹"
h3. Workaround

Commits made from other sources (e.g. from your local copy and pushed to Bitbucket) are displayed correctly
fields.summary: In-browser editor's commit message dialogue doesn't support non-latin characters

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Security Team requires all access to projects and repositories come from "logged in" users.  We want to provide read-only access to all users without using a license seat.  The need to log in is for security auditing purposes.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a new permission level below "Bitbucket User" which provides Read-Only access and does not use licenses.

h3. Why this is important
Security Team requires user accounts for auditing purposes.
 
h3. Workaround
Enable "Public Access" to projects and repositories, and perform user account auditing at the network level.
fields.summary: Read-only, Unlicensened, User Accounts

fields.description:
In BitBucket Server pull-request list, it is unclear which of the pull-request can be merged and which does not because of merge criteria or conflicts.

It will be very helpful to see in this list the following information _If the pull request stands with the merge criteria ( #reviewers, #builds),_ If the pull request has conflicts and therefore cannot be merged

In addition it will be helpful to have a "Merge" button in the pull-request list so integrator can merge the pull-request without going into the pull-request details. After all it has been reviewed and verified.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Server - State Mergeable/Unmergeable in the pull request list

fields.description: Now it's hardcoded to 3, 4 or 5 depends on page where reviewer lists is used. Will be nice to have configuration property of this.
fields.summary: Configure maxOpen in reviewer-avatar-list via bitbucket.propeties

fields.description:
h3. Summary 

The right to left support required to allow fully utilizing the Hebrew language reading this also required for the Arabic language. Due to its nature of reading and writing of the mentioned the language scripts which is from right to left this would be much efficient in the Bitbucket Server GUI.
fields.summary: Right-to-Left typing support

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you have image files that are _not_ LFS-tracked inside a repo, then enable LFS tracking, the commits immediately before and after enabling LFS tracking will show a broken "diff to previous" state.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an empty repo with a test image
# Modify the image and push to repo
# Confirm image diffing works
# Enable LFS tracking for the image and push to the repo
# Confirm image diff is broken between the pre-LFS and post-LFS commit
# Modify the image again and push to repo
# Confirm image diff works again


h3. Expected Results
Image diff continues to work

h3. Actual Results
Between the transitional (pre-LFS and post-LFS) commits, Bitbucket appears to diff the previous image with the text pointer file, resulting in a broken image: 
!imagediff_test.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Enabling LFS tracking for an existing image file breaks diff between the pre-LFS and post-LFS commits

fields.description:
Enhance mail subsystem to log details about mail messages when eaither succesfully processed or failures during processing.

The following table details the information required for successfully delivered mails.
||Property||Description||Why||
|Sender email| |Tracability|
|Recipient email| |Tracability|
|Start time|When the SMTP operation started| |
|Duration of SMTP operation|How long the message took to send to the SMTP server|Debugging|
|Time on mail queue|How long the message was queued in BBS|Debugging|
|Current mail queue size|Indication of mail queue depth|Debugging|
|SMTP Message ID|For tractability throughout various network elements |Tracability|

In addition to the success log message details, when an error occurs the log should contain the exact response / response code from the SMTP server if possible.
fields.summary: Enhanced logging for Bitbucket Mail

fields.description:
We used your utility method com.atlassian.bitbucket.ao.AoUtils#lengthFunction, unfortunately this method has a problem.

Function _LEN_ in MS SQL doesn`t support some column types, in particular _NTEXT_.

If ao entity has a String type field  with annotation _@StringLength(UNLIMITED)_, [the column with type NTEXT will be generated|https://developer.atlassian.com/docs/atlassian-platform-common-components/active-objects/ao-0-18-x-upgrade-guide#AO0.18.xUpgradeGuide-TypeChanges] and throw an exeption when the function is called.

 
{noformat}
com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: Argument data type ntext is invalid for argument 1 of len function.
com.atlassian.activeobjects.internal.ActiveObjectsSqlException: There was a SQL exception thrown by the Active Objects library:
Database:
               - name:Microsoft SQL Server
               - version:11.00.6020
               - minor version:0
               - major version:11
Driver:
               - name:Microsoft JDBC Driver 6.0 for SQL Server
               - version:6.0.7507.100
com.microsoft.sqlserver.jdbc.SQLServerException: Argument data type ntext is invalid for argument 1 of len function.
               at com.atlassian.activeobjects.internal.EntityManagedActiveObjects.stream(EntityManagedActiveObjects.java:166) ~[na:na]
               at com.atlassian.activeobjects.osgi.TenantAwareActiveObjects.stream(TenantAwareActiveObjects.java:316) ~[na:na]

{noformat}
 

To get the length for the  type _NTEXT_ it is necessary to use _DATALENGTH_ function
fields.summary: AoUtils#lengthFunction Problem in MS SQL

fields.description:
Invalid recipients or senders for emails cause the MailService to pause for 5 seconds (by default) as this is caught as a general `MailException` and not differentiated from a network failure etc.

In systems where recipients mailed to are frequently invalid (e.g. an employee leaving but remaining on several active PRs) this can degrade mail throughput especially for systems at scale.
fields.summary: Routine SMTP errors like invalid recipients pause MailService for 5 or more seconds
BatchNotificationJob does not respond to a request to cancel()

fields.description:
When encountering a large number of pending notifications, BatchProcessorJob will spin through them all, generating email copy in-memory and enqueue the MailMessage with the MailService. This causes immediate CPU pressure through the email generation process, medium term memory pressure as the emails accumulate if the MailService cannot send them as quickly as they are enqueued and it also strains the customer's email infrastructure as it deals with a deluge of notifications from BB.

MailService should be rate limited in general but it's arguable that BatchProcessorJob needs it sooner as it performs enqueues in a non-blocking fashion and so isn't responsive to rate-limiting in the MailService except where that manifests itself as a MailQueueFullException on the call to submit
fields.summary: MailServer and/or BatchNotificationJob need configurable rate limiting

fields.description:
If MailQueueFullException is thrown the notification job continues on its merry way shovelling more email into an already full queue. Better would be to gracefully finish the current job early, performing any usual housework that is done, and try again next time.

Current behaviour simply drops any batch email that is unlucky enough to be generated with the queue is full.
fields.summary: Notification processing should abort the current job if the mail queue is full

Actual behaviour: nothing happens

fields.description:
An anonymous user can gain read-only access to some administrative pages by crafting a malicious GET request. This vulnerability was originally detected in [Spring Security (CVE-5006)|https://pivotal.io/security/cve-2016-5007].

*Customers who have downloaded and installed Bitbucket Server (formerly Stash) >= 2.4.2 less than 4.8.x*
Please *upgrade your Bitbucket Server (formerly Stash)* installations to fix this vulnerability.

A known fix for this problem is detailed below:
{noformat}
<!-- JSR-303 (bean validations) support will be detected on classpath and enabled automatically -->
    <mvc:annotation-driven validator="validator">
        <mvc:message-converters>
            <bean class="org.springframework.http.converter.BufferedImageHttpMessageConverter"/>
        </mvc:message-converters>
        <mvc:path-matching suffix-pattern="false"  path-matcher="pathMatcher"  />
    </mvc:annotation-driven>
    <bean id="pathMatcher" class="org.springframework.util.AntPathMatcher">
	    <property name="trimTokens" value="false" />
    </bean>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Spring Security / MVC Path Matching Inconsistency

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you push a non-tracked version of a file to Bitbucket Server, then enable lfs and push an lfs-tracked version of the file, the download of the lfs version in a diff returns the pointer file.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Commit a binary file to a vanilla git repository.
# Push to a vanilla git Bitbucket Server repository.
# Convert local repository and the Bitbucket Server repository to git-lfs.
# Track the binary file type using git-lfs.
# Commit an update to the binary file.
# Push to Bitbucket Server.
# View the new version in a diff in Bitbucket Server.

h3. Expected Results
The lfs pointer is de-referenced and the new version of the binary is made available to download 

h3. Actual Results
Text output showing lfs pointer

 h3. Notes
Old version (non-lfs) of the file is available to download

h3.Workaround
None at this time
fields.summary: Diff download link provides the lfs pointer if the diff is tracked to non-tracked file

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When using the importing tool and the GitHub Enterprise option, the import fails with a 400 (invalid url) response when the URL has a custom top level domain.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to Import tool in Web UI
 # Select GitHub Enterprise option
 # Enter a URL for a repo with a custom tld (eg. [https://nates.repo.pvt|https://nates.repo.pvt/])

h3. Expected Results

Repo is imported if it can be reached
h3. Actual Results

We use the Apache Commons UrlValidator ([https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/UrlValidator.html]) library to check the URL. This also checks if the Top Level Domain (TLD) is one of the valid ones according to the RFC spec (it uses DomainValidator - [https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-validator/apidocs/org/apache/commons/validator/routines/DomainValidator.html]). {{pvt}} is not a valid TLD, so it fails validation

The below 400 error is seen in the atlassian-access.log file:
{code:java}
1XX.XX.XXX.XXX | http | i@1G2MZ9Rx886x1328x0 | - | 2017-01-17 14:46:32,362 | "POST /rest/importer/latest/external-source/missing-oauth-scopes HTTP/1.1" | "http://nate.bitbucket.com:7990/plugins/servlet/import-repository/myrepo" "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36" | - | - | - | - | - | rqx5li | 
1XX.XX.XXX.XXX | http | o@1G2MZ9Rx886x1328x0 | myuser | 2017-01-17 14:46:32,362 | "POST /rest/importer/latest/external-source/missing-oauth-scopes HTTP/1.1" | "http://nate.bitbucket/com:7990/plugins/servlet/import-repository/myrepo" "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/55.0.2883.87 Safari/537.36" | 400 | 178 | 225 | - | 4 | rqx5li |{code}
If a HAR file is generated when the issue is replicated we see the following response from Bitbucket Server: 
{code:java}
"message": "The specified URL is invalid: https://nates.repo.pvt/api/v3/users/myuser"{code}
fields.summary: Importing a Github Enterprise repo (using the importer tool) fails if the top level domain is not valid (custom)

fields.description:
If notification processing is blocked for some reason (db connections not available, Hazelcast deadlock etc) and does not fully finish then stale notifications will not be purged. On subsequent restart of the app, all pending notifications including stale ones will be sent immediately which, depending on the activity and length of time since successful notification processing, can cause emails to fail to send because they exceed the per-email size limit or the mail queue fills up suddenly.

We should purge stale notifications at the beginning of the job and also stop the job early (until the next interval) when the mail queue is near or at capacity.
fields.summary: Blocked notification processing may cause email deluge on next restart

fields.description:
Some mail servers and mail proxies treat the NOOP SMTP command as a trigger to slow down communication between the mail client and the mail server resulting in delayed mail delivery.

*Important:* it is important to note that some anti-virus software interfere with normal SMTP operations and can be the root cause of incorrect command pipe lining of SMTP commands. I have not investigated this in detail, because this is outside of the scope of this story.

*Sendmail* by default only allows 20 NOOP instructions before closing the connection to the mail client.  A snippet from the O'Reilly Sendmail (4th edition)

 
{noformat}
Prior to V8.14, the only way to change the limit on useless commands was to change the setting for 
the MAXNOOPCOMMANDS compile-time macro in sendmail/srvrsmtp.c. 

Beginning with V8.14, however, you may override that default with your own limit by setting this 
MaxNOOPCommands option, which is declared like this:

O MaxNOOPCommands=num          ← configuration file (V8.14 and later)
-OMaxNOOPCommands=num          ← command line (V8.14 and later)
define(`confMAX_NOOP_COMMANDS',`num') ← mc configuration (V8.14 and later)

Here, num is of type numeric. If num is negative, non-numeric, or zero, 
no limit is placed on the number of useless commands that the client may send. 
If this option is entirely omitted, the default is the original value of 20.
{noformat}
From a bug report to Sendmail:
{noformat}
We have some code that sends out emails to our customers. The way our
code is currently written, it uses the SMTP NOOP command to see if the
connection is still open. We deployed it over the weekend and
everything worked, but we noticed that emails were being sent out
*very* slowly, at the rate of one every 4 minutes.

After a lot of debugging, it turns out that sendmail, after about 20
NOOP commands, starts delaying the responses to these, 1 second, 2
seconds, 4 seconds, etc., up until 4 minutes. This is an antispam
feature apparently.{noformat}
*Postfix* documentation indicates that they don't recommend clients sending NOOP commands to keep network connections alive. The reasoning is not clear, but they seem to imply that it results in extra server load to keep these IDLE connections open. The text below taken from postfix.org documentation about how to configure Postfix as a production mail server. 
{noformat}
Use an smtpd_junk_command_limit of 1 instead of the default 100. 
This prevents clients from keeping idle connections open by repeatedly sending NOOP or RSET commands.{noformat}
*Microsoft Exchange Server* also seems to be affected, eventually closing the connection to the mail client with the following message:
{noformat}
NOOP 
250 2.0.0 OK 
NOOP 
250 2.0.0 OK 
NOOP 
250 2.0.0 OK 
NOOP 
250 2.0.0 OK 
421 Too many errors on this connection---closing{noformat}
The general trend seems to be open a connection when required, send emails and disconnect. NOOP and RSET commands can be used to keep connections alive but they should be avoided.
fields.summary: Allow MailService to use SMTP RSET command instead NOOP

fields.description:
We have customers that would like to restrict the merge strategies a repository/project admin can choose from in the pull request repository settings. This is so administrators can enforce a subset of merge strategies company wide.

Currently the only way to do this is through some JavaScript loaded onto the page which hides the merge strategies from the repository/project admin. However they are still able to enable/disable through the REST API.

We have had a few customers request this for ScriptRunner for Bitbucket Server and currently there is no better way to do this.

It would be good to publish a cancellable event when the selected merge strategies are updated for a particular repository, it could contain the repository and the original and the updated merge strategies. Then we can prevent some strategies from being enabled based on some logic the user defines which would also be more flexible and faster than the user manually restricting them per repository.
fields.summary: Restrict selected pull request merge strategies in repository settings by publishing a cancellable event

fields.description:
The embedded LFS object store in Bitbucket Server can (and by default does) enforce a minimum free disk space requirement, so as to prevent completely filling a filesystem with LFS objects. This is described in the section "Limiting Disk Space Usage" [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer0411/Git+Large+File+Storage].

To determine the amount of free disk space on the filesystem that hosts LFS objects Bitbucket Server uses [FileStore.getUsableSpace()|https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/FileStore.html#getUsableSpace--]. If this fails with an IOException two things are logged:

1) An error that says "Failed to retrieve free space for filesystem" (including the full exception stack trace); and
2) An error that says "Insufficient free space in store" (also including a stack trace)

We should only log 1 in the case the call to {{getUsableSpace()}} fails; logging 2 is confusing.

Part of the reason 2 is logged is because in the case the system fails to determine the available free disk space, we treat it the same as if the disk is full, the upload is failed to avoid exceeding the free disk space threshold.
fields.summary: Git LFS: Ambiguous logging when failing to determine free disk space

h3. Summary

There is a discrepancy between the data shown in JIRA's dev summary panel and what's really in Bitbucket Server. For old branches/issues, this data will never get refreshed.  (This is due to a discrepancy between the AO JIRA_INDEX table and sta_pull_request)

h3. Environment

Bitbucket Server 4.6.2 with many 3rd party add-ons

h3. Steps to Reproduce

Unknown

h3. Expected Results

The data shown in the dev summary panel and the state of PRs in Bitbucket Server should be in-sync.

h3. Actual Results

The data shown in the dev summary panel shows the PR as OPEN when it's actually merged

h3. Notes
* There was a suggestion that this issue was caused by third-party plugins but we have seen this (rarely) on our internal Atlassian Bitbucket Server instance, so we know it can happen without them, too.
* Without "steps to reproduce", it's hard to know where to start on this bug. Perhaps we could provide some way to manually refresh the data (with a "reload" button in the dev summary panel?). That's not an elegant solution but we aren't seeing this issue often enough to think the feature needs significant hardening, either.

If I push a tag, or anything not to refs/heads/*, we shouldn't see the 'create a pull request' output from terminal.

The problem is that people are seeing that they can create a PR from our automation which pushes to non-standard refs, and then they attempt to do so, when it is not supported

Anton Genkin

fields.description:
TLDR: Add X-FRAME-Options: SAMEORIGIN to all HTTP(S) pages (server config), and test that nothing breaks.
 —
 *Description:* HTTP headers on requests that start with {{/plugins/servlet/}} do not contain the X-FRAME-Option, which helps prevents against Clickjacking attacks. A Clickjacking attack is similar to CSRF in which attacker can hijack a "click" on a web application from another "invisible" frame in the browser. Essentially, an attacker can force a user to click on a button that is invisible to him/her.

We already set the {{X-Frame-Options}} header for most URLs  exceptions are the login page and the {{/plugins/servlet/.*}} paths that are currently whitelisted.

The header should be added to those paths too. 

 

*Exploit Scenario:* An attacker crafts a malicious page such that when their victim clicks, they are actually clicking on the link or button in the vulnerable application hosted in an iframe. Thus, an attacker tricks the user into performing an action of the attacker's choosing by directing mouse input to the target application.
h3. Workaround

Applying an additional header to the Apache HTTP server can mitigate this problem. Specifically using the SAMEORIGIN setting. If the header contains the SAMEORIGIN option, the response will be loaded within a frame only if the parent page is from the same origin.

For Apache:
 # Add this to your {{httpd.conf}} file:
{code:java}
Header always setifempty X-Frame-Options SAMEORIGIN
{code}
 # Ensure the headers module is enabled, the below is required in {{httpd.conf}}, or if using Ubuntu/Debian {{a2enmod headers}} will turn it on.
{code:java}
LoadModule headers_module modules/mod_headers.so
{code}
 # Restart Apache.

Note that this is not a panacea for clickjacking. SAMEORIGIN should be safe to use and not provide any negative side-effects.
fields.summary: Enable X-FRAME-Options header to implement clickjacking protection

fields.description: There have been a number of security issues in non-atlassian software caused by using the HOST header of an incoming request. Therefore, this suggestion issue to request that when Bitbucket Server sees a request with a HOST header that does not match the instance's server url to redirect the request to the server url.

h3. Problem Definition
It's currently possible to enable Git LFS in Bitbucket Server without having to enable HTTP(S) access. Git LFS requires HTTP to be enabled, however this may not be obvious to users as Bitbucket gives no indication that this is the case

If Git LFS is enabled but HTTP(S) access is not, display a warning to the user, or prevent the user from saving without correcting this configuration option.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
* add {{feature.public.access=true}} on {{<bitbucket-home>/shared/bitbucket.properties}}
* under {{http://localhost:7990/projects/PROJ/permissions}} leave:
** {{Project permissions >> Public access}} disabled
|| \[ \] |Enable|
** {{Project permissions >> Default Permission}} with no access
|| \[ \] |No access|
* clone a repository
{code}
git clone http://localhost:7990/scm/proj/repository.git
{code}
{code}
git remote -v
origin	http://localhost:7990/scm/proj/repository.git (fetch)
origin	http://localhost:7990/scm/proj/repository.git (push)
{code}

{code}echo "file" > file.txt{code}
{code}git add file.txt{code}
{code}git commit -m "add file"{code}

h3. Expected Results

h3. Actual Results

{code}

fields.description:
Branches without any commits cannot be deleted when created in a repository with a branch deletion permission matching the branch name.  This can occur when work is rejected or deferred and requires having to obtain temporary special permissions to each repository for which this branch was created to delete them, to merge a branch without any changes or to leave a branch that dead ends and is never merged.

It would be great to have an additional branch permission to not allow branches to be deleted which have at least one commit, allowing branches which match the name and without any commits to be deleted.
fields.summary: Branch Permissions: Allow deleting branch only if no commits have been made

fields.description:
When there is a merge conflict in an automatic merge by Bitbucket, a developer has to create a new branch, perform the merge, resolve the conflicts, and then file a pull request.  The diff in the pull request shows the full set of changes introduced by the merge, most of which have already been reviewed before.  The changes for the merge conflict resolution can be lost in all the other changes, particularly if it's a big merge.

What we really want to review in the pull request are the changes for the merge conflict resolution.  These are where problems are often introduced.

The changes are readily available with 'git show <merge hash>' or 'git diff-tree --cc <merge hash>'.  This is the view we'd like to see when reviewing a merge commit.

A nice description is given here: http://haacked.com/archive/2014/02/21/reviewing-merge-commits/
fields.summary: Better Review of Merge Commit

fields.description: Since 4.11.x footer does not exists on dashboard page.
fields.summary: Where is no footer on dashboard page

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Certain Database updates happen every time a user authenticates with Bitbucket. This can be the result of a REST call using Basic auth, a login using the web UI or an authentication via Git.
Some of these updates don't need to happen on every authentication, if they have occurred very recently. 
Examples of this are updating the user's last authenticated timestamp, or recently accessed repository list. 

h3. Suggested Solution

"Gate" the number of updates we do, in order to reduce the number of updates in the Database. 
This means, only update the last authenticated timestamp and recently accessed repositories a maximum of once every 60 seconds, per user.
fields.summary: Reduce Database load by 'gating' the number of non-critical updates done

fields.description:
Having multiple parallel graphs (in our case supported release versions), we often need to track down where a branch branched off from another one and then go through the commits since this branching point. Tracing back is somewhat feasible using the "Parents: ..." links in the commit details view. However, there is no way to go "back up" i.e. "back to the previously selected commit".

I think for this and many other scenarios, it would be helpful if SourceTree would store a history of selected commits, similar to a browser's history of visited websites for each tab. Just like in a browser, I envision "go back" and "go forward" buttons in the top button menu which would allow to jump back and forth between the previous commit selections (and gray out if one reaches either end of the history stack). If the user previously selected multiple commits, this multi-selection should probably be restored as well.

Just like we already have "Parents: ..." links for each commit, it may also be helpful to have "Children: ..." links for each commit. However, for our use-cases, the browser like "go back" and "go forward" buttons would be more helpful.
fields.summary: "go back" / "go forward" in History view

h3. Problem Definition

Trying to make highlight working for Lists using the following syntax:
{noformat}
Feature: this is a feature description
@create
Scenario: Create a todo item with invalid data
Given I am a user who can manage todos
When I create a todo item with invalid data
Then I should receive a payload constraint violation error with the following invalid properties:
| name |
| description |
{noformat}
the last part of the code gets highlighted as a table
 !Screen Shot 2016-12-09 at 16.56.17.png|thumbnail! 

While it should be highlighted a simple list, unless the {{Example:}} keyword is used.

This is due to a bug in the CodeMirror library reported at [https://github.com/codemirror/CodeMirror/issues/4425]
h3. Suggested Solution

Monitor the CodeMirror issue resolution and include a new version of the CodeMirror library once the bug is fixed there.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

While it is currently possible in Bitbucket Server to [globally define merge strategies|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-config-properties-776640155.html#BitbucketServerconfigproperties-Pullrequests] for pull requests, this setting can be overridden on a per-repository basis. Depending on the strategy used during merge, information may be lost (by removing commits rather than creating a merge commit) that links commits to JIRA issues, pull requests, etc, which is critical information to maintain for audit purposes.
h3. Suggested Solution

There should be a way for an administrator to define a non-overridable merge strategy to be applied to all repositories.
h3. Workaround

Don't give anyone repository admin permissions. That way, only the project admin can modify these settings.
fields.summary: As an administrator I want to define a non-overridable merge strategy for pull requests

fields.description:
According to https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/server/docs/latest/how-tos/updating-build-status-for-commits.html
Bitbucket Server accepts only 3 possible outcomes from a build: INPROGRESS|SUCCESSFUL|FAILED.
Yet sometimes (e.g. build is cancelled, agent was taken down, etc.) the outcome is INCONCLUSIVE - it's neither success or fail, it's not in progress either.

Some may argue such state should be represented as FAILED, but we have requests to distinguish INCONCLUSIVE from FAILED outcome, see BAM-18089
fields.summary: Introduce new build status state: INCONCLUSIVE

fields.description: Diff to previous on the source page breaks on empty diffs, for instance when the contents of the diff is only whitespace changes and the "Ignore whitespace" option is turned on.
fields.summary: Diff to previous breaks on empty diffs

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently Bitbucket Server allows administrators to prevent history rewrites on a per-repository basis. For customers from certain industries with strict regulatory requirements (such as banking and healthcare) it is essential that the repository history is trustworthy and non-modifiable through history rewrites. In those situations it is tedious to manually enable the option to prevent history rewrites in every repository.

Additionally, while a Bitbucket Server administrator can enable the option in a repository, an administrator of that repository can disable the option again, and every user can toggle history rewrites on their own personal repositories, which makes it impossible to guarantee the required history integrity.

h3. Suggested Solution

An option should be added that allows a Bitbucket Server administrator to disable history rewrites for all repositories (including personal ones) with the option of not allowing project/repo administrators to override the setting.

h3. Workaround

There is currently no workaround available that cannot be overridden.
fields.summary: As an administrator I want to globally prevent history rewrites for all repositories

fields.description:
h3. Problem definition
Bitbucket Server ver4.6+ that comes with ElasticSearch is not effective for performing search repository with partial string after '.' or '_' return with incorrect or no results. It appears that search code detects '-' as a word boundary. 

Performing the search with wildcards such as '%' or '?' does not provide any results as it would in previous versions(without ElasticSearch).

h3. Suggested solution
N/A

h3. Workaround
Type out the repository name from the initial string for the best match.

h4. Why this is important
-Preforming repository search with categorized first, second and so on with set of strings that separated by word boundaries or separators  such '.', '-' -or '_' would be laborious.-

Performing repository search on repository names using '_' or '.' as substring separators is laborious, because the substrings are not detected
fields.summary: Search repository with wildcard is ineffective

fields.summary: Bitbucket hover for commit messages render too few columns

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Unable to create a branch from JIRA issue in case that some special characters are immediately after "." in the summary.

h3. Environment

* JIRA Software 7.2.6

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Integrate Bitbucket Server with JIRA Software
# Create a issue whose summary is "test.<special character>" (e.g. "test./", "test.[")
(i) Please replace <special character> with a special character
# Create a branch from the issue (You can select any {{Repository}}, {{Branch type}}, {{Branch from}})

h3. Expected Results

The special character and the dot "." should be trimmed appropriately and {{<issue key>-test}} should be created.

h3. Actual Results

Only the special character was trimmed and "." wasn't.
That's why, the branch name was set to {{<issue key>-test.}} and it was unable to create the branch with the following error.
 
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Notes
This problem seems to be an edge case of BSERV-4961.

h3.Workaround
Rename the branch manually.
fields.summary: Unable to create branch from JIRA issue in case that some special characters are immediately after "." in the summary

fields.description:
Hello,

In Bitbucket we use an internal SSO plugin for the login so that you cannot introduce a login/password to log using another user. Compared to JIRA and Confluence when you logout on Bitbucket you're automatically redirected to a page that contains only the login button which it's not the case for JIRA and Confluence which redirect to a login page on which you can introduce your credentials.

Based on that users cannot get access to a login page. We are ourselves blocked in several admin tasks because of this.

Did you plan to align the three products to use the same pattern?

 

Thank you.

 

Cheers,
Ahmed

Once the settings are saved, the connection to Elasticsearch fails and the search feature is not available in Bitbucket Server.

h3. Suggested Solution
Protect the Elasticsearch password against this condition.
fields.summary: Protect the Elasticsearch password against unwanted changes

fields.summary: Permission issue when configuring Default Reviewers

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Branch permissions are limited to 100 total permissions by default. This limit isn't documented clearly anywhere, and it's not obvious to the user when they're near this limit (as it is defined per individual permission, rather than per set of branch permissions). It's also not clear how to resolve the issue - "learn more" links back to the Using branch permissions page, but there is no mention of any limitation on that page.

h3. Suggested Solution
Add a user visible element to the branch permissions page showing how many are in use. A brief description of how to resolve the issue would also be helpful

h3. Workaround
[Bitbucket Server config properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Bitbucket+Server+config+properties#BitbucketServerconfigproperties-refrestriction] does document how to increase ref restrictions, and increasing the limits described here will resolve the issue.
fields.summary: Increase visibility of ref restriction/branch permission limits

fields.description:
When merging commits between branches, all the JIRA issues from the other branch are linked in the pull request. This is then confusing, since it shows a lot of other issues linked in the pull request that isn't part of that specific branch.
Ideally only the JIRA issues that was part of commits directly to a branch should be linked
fields.summary: Don't link Jira issues from merge commits

fields.description:
JMX clients like jconsole use the JMX server port (which is random by default and *not* 3333) to communicate with bitbucket server. This makes it difficult to open the right firewall port on the server to permit JMX access. See, e.g., [http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20884353/why-java-opens-3-ports-when-jmx-is-configured/21552812#21552812].

A simple fix can be made in {{bin/setenv.sh}}. That file currently adds "{{-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.port=$\{JMX_REMOTE_PORT}}}" to {{JMX_OPTS}} (in two places). It could add "{{-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.rmi.port=$\{JMX_REMOTE_PORT}}}" as well.
fields.summary: Force the JMX server port (random by default) to be the same as the JMX registry port (3333) so it can be opened on firewalls

fields.description:
{panel}
(!) *Note*: This bug is fixed in Bitbucket Server 4.13 but third-party plugins (particularly plugins that check new commits as they are pushed) may also be impacted by the changes in git 2.11.
{panel}
h3. Summary

When the "Reject Force Push" hook is enabled and the Git version is 2.11.0, all pushes to the repository fail even when the {{--force}} option is not used.
h3. Steps to reproduce
 # Spin up Bitbucket Server using git v2.11.0
 # Create a new repository and push an initial commit to it
 # Turn the "Reject Force Push" pre-receive hook on OR setup branch permissions to prevent writing history on your branch
 # Create a new commit and attempt to push it to Bitbucket Server

h3. Expected Results

Push is successful.
h3. Actual Results

Push is blocked by a pre-receive hook (or branch permissions).
h3. Cause

From the [git 2.11 release notes|https://github.com/git/git/blob/v2.11.0/Documentation/RelNotes/2.11.0.txt]:
{quote}In order for the receiving end of "git push" to inspect the
 received history and decide to reject the push, the objects sent
 from the sending end need to be made available to the hook and
 the mechanism for the connectivity check, and this was done
 traditionally by storing the objects in the receiving repository
 and letting "git gc" expire them. Instead, store the newly
 received objects in a temporary area, and make them available by
 reusing the alternate object store mechanism to them only while we
 decide if we accept the check, and once we decide, either migrate
 them to the repository or purge them immediately.
{quote}
h3. Workaround

Downgrade to Git 2.10.x or older. Any version after Git 2.11.0 (including future 2.12+ releases) cannot be used with Bitbucket Server.

Bitbucket Server 4.12 will fail on startup if Git 2.11+ is detected. However, older versions of Bitbucket Server (and Stash) are not aware of the 2.11 issues (since it was released after they were), _but will still be broken by them_. Administrators are _strongly encouraged_ to only upgrade to Git versions which are _explicitly marked supported_ on our [Supported Platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Supported+platforms] for the version of the product they're running.
fields.summary: Pre-receive hooks and branch permissions reject valid pushes on git 2.11

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
With the addition of Dashboards, the unauthenticated homepage layout change from showing only public projects to showing all public shared and personal repositories.

h3. Suggested Solution.
* Change the layout back
OR
* Add an option to change the homepage layout back

h3. Why this is important
{quote}We use public repositories to advertise major projects/repositories that we want people outside of R&D to see and have access to. Personal repositories are not included in that list. Under the previous behavior, these public personal repos were not actively advertised to [unauthenticated] users.

As an admin, I don't really want to advertise peoples personal repositories.

Ultimately, I'm looking for control of what's visible to outside users. If they are given a direct Git URL for a public personal repo, I expect them to be able to clone that repo I just don't want it advertised on the front page of Bitbucket.{quote} 

h3. Workaround 
Identify all users with public personal repositories and ask them to make them private.
fields.summary: As an Admin, I would like the option to change the unauthenticated home page back to the 4.9 layout

fields.description:
Right now we use the API here to generate pull requests automatically as part of our ci workflow: https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.10.1/bitbucket-rest.html#idp896512

This works great, but due to the way we’re set up, we have an automation user (cl_buildbot) that supplies its credentials to generate this pull request. Because of the way Bitbucket works, this means that cl_buildbot is also the owner of the pull request, even though it is creating the pull request on behalf of someone else.

This makes managing PRs a little difficult on Stash, since they’re all generated by one user.

We would rather not manually generate pull requests as this is inconvenient.

We would also really rather not have to have each submitter supply credentials to the buildbot (for authenticating via the API) as this is both very inconvenient and not so secure.


So simply allowing us to set the owner at creation time (or after the fact) would be a major improvement.
fields.summary: Bitbucket pull request creation API should have an option to set the owner

{panel:title=Atlassian status as of July 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi,

Good news! Starting from Bitbucket Data Center 7.3 you can find _AuthenticationFailureEvent_ and _SshAuthenticationFailure_ in the Audit log. These events contain information about the user and time of a restricted access attempt. The events will be raised if the coverage level of _Security_ is set to _Advanced_. For more information, please read Audit log [docs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/audit-log-events-in-bitbucket-776640423.html].

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}

*Original message*
I have a branch setup to only allow push requests from certain users all other users have to use a pull request. I was trying to find out why my Bamboo push was being denied from Bitbucket by viewing an audit log of the denied push but I could not find one.

It would be nice to see a log of the denial that the server issued based on security. I would think this would be extended to all security events being logged so we can watch-out for malicious activity on the repository.
fields.summary: Security Audit log for denied actions

fields.description:
In Stash 3.9, a {{label}} column was added to the {{sta_service_user}} table, which is used to distinguish different types of service users.

When the column was added, the SSH upgrade task that creates service users for access keys (created before 2.10), was not updated to also set the appropriate label for these service users. As a result, the service users that are created as part of the upgrade task as created with the default 'bot' label instead of the 'access-key' label.

The migrated access keys work fine, but cannot be deleted. See BSERV-8388.

This issue covers fixing the upgrade task to correctly set the label. This will ensure that upgrades from 3.8 and lower to 4.12 and higher will not have the problem described in BSERV-8388.

It does not correct the {{label}} on incorrectly upgraded {{sta_service_user as}} for instances that have migrated from 3.8 (or lower) to 3.9 - 4.11. That will be fixed as part of BSERV-8388.
fields.summary: Upgrade from Stash 2.11 and lower to 3.9 - 4.11 does not set correct service user label for migrated access keys

fields.description:
Some users like to transition JIRA issues to "Resolved" state using BitBucket integration with JIRA. The JIRA-BitBucket integration seems to have a few issues:

1. The "Visibility" custom field gets reset to the default value "Undecided" when resolving on the BitBucket side. The current value is ignored and overwritten
2. The description of the fields is missing on the BitBucket side
3. The order of the fields is changed on the BitBucket side
4. The "Comment" field is missing on the BitBucket side

The main issue is (1) (the others are cosmetic, (1) corrupts our JIRA issues). Note that "Visibility" is the only custom field with a default and a pre-existing value that we have in that screen, so I can't say the problem is specific to the "Visibility" field or generic to any custom field that might have been pre-existing (as opposed to determined/entered during resolution). In other words, it might be that BitBucket does not (or cannot?) get current values from the JIRA issue. This would explain why it doesn't show the "Verifier" field, but then it should not show the "Visibility" field either.

In the meantime, I need a way to disable JIRA state transitions from within BitBucket, because corrupting the "Visibility" field has customer impact (it changes release noted issues to "internal", even on the external bug management tool side through integration).
fields.summary: JIRA-BitBucket integration: custom select fields get reset

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

The default development branch doesn't exist in a current branching and release strategy. A 1 branch policy per release strategy is followed instead. 

If everyone has their own branching strategy as suit to their product development why is the development branch mandatory?

Please see attached image for implemented branching and merge strategy.

As per that it is desired to have automatic release branch merge from current release branch to next release branch and so on. This is the only merge flow currently implemented and there is need to enable automatic release branch merge for the same.

h3. Suggested Solution

Make development branch optional
fields.summary: As a user I would like the development branch to be optional with respect to the branching model and automerging
